_decoded_content.title: Improved dbt integration
_decoded_content.description:
It's now incredibly easy to get started with Singer-based data extraction and loading using Meltano, but transformation using dbt hasn't received a lot of love over the past few months, despite it being advertised on our homepage (https://meltano.com/#transformation) and users in Slack showing a clear interest in this functionality.

In this epic, we'll track issues related to improving the situation, including the docs at https://meltano.com/docs/transforms.html.

_decoded_content.title: Move Meltano to GitHub
_decoded_content.description:
## Why:
* we need to lower the barrier to contribution to become truly ubiquitous and support a huge amount of (community-contributed) plugins.
* network effects 
* Improved Discoverability 
* More people have GitHub accounts so it makes it easier to get started and work with us
* Will help speed up onboarding since more dev are experienced using GH

## Timing: 
* May 30th- Migration
* May 31- announce in blog, social, slack

* Get Meltano/Hub/SDK code repos done before 2.0 so we can benefit from the publicity and avoid disruption while we have added attention - other repos can come soon after
* It will be disruptive no matter when we do it so let's do it before we have more to move

## Goals:
* Get more stars
* Lower barrier to contribute and try

_decoded_content.title: Kitcaster (podcasting) Q4 and Q1
_decoded_content.description:
**Copy and paste the checklist below for all interviews and create an issue and associate with this epic**

## Getting the most out of every episode/ process:
Once booked the following checklist needs to happen...
- [ ] send cal invite for podcast and add Emily and Amanda to the invite so we know when recording is happening and we can plan social 
- [ ] communicate to marketing launch date and when we will get video. transcript (add cal invite whenever possible)
- [ ] possible strategy call before recording to discuss key positioning, points, and CTA

#### on podcast
- [ ] push CTA and key points
- [ ] if it is a potential investor sourcing opportunity... "Mention in the interview we are preparing to raise a round of funding and describe out ideal investor relationship and how much money you need."
- [ ] thanks the host and let them know we will be promoting the episode and ask if there is anything else we can do to help
- [ ] ask when it will go live
- [ ] if there is a connection say you would like to stay in touch if possible (needs to be followed up with a personal email a couple of days later)

#### for marketing post podcast
- [ ] schedule and craft social plans (must tag host and podcast name in posts)
- [ ] Collect video snippets and any relevant artwork 
- [ ] collect key quotes for promotion
- [ ] craft plan for continued promotion and content creation opportunities
   - [ ] repurpose video/ audio
   - [ ] transcribe text
   - [ ] create blog posts/ newsletter from content 
   - [ ] create PR pitch for future


@DouweM please read the [raising money section of this article](https://kitcaster.com/leveraging-podcast-interviews/)


<!-- Labels to add for triaging -->

_decoded_content.title: Draft.dev writer program
_decoded_content.description:
[**Link to content planning and all drafts**](https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1oCeDtm3vwH14a1ADcgzccfTmz_ReX0wI6PJvl2gp7TM/edit?usp=drive_web&ouid=113880846901922259846)

## Activity / why we need this
This would be good for some evergreen content, whitepapers or maybe the occasional really complex tutorial. 

It’s expensive, but seems that hiring a bunch of cheaper folks will result in us editing and hand-holding to get things across the finish line. 

Amanda noted: That was the case with the GitLab/Nexmo writers programs and we don’t have someone to manage that yet.

It is clear having us write everything internally is not scaling and no one has time to create the volume we need to make a dent. 

Benefits:
- Nice that it’s mostly a flat rate.
- We only have to commit to a quarter at a time
- have no doubt in the quality and we get the added benefit of educating the writer's network 
- easy to scale up or down
- frees up our own team's time and we don't need to hire someone full time
- content not coming from us can have the added benefit of seeming more authentic
- all trained in SEO and they offer keyword research 
- can help create a steady drumbeat of content 4-10 blog posts a month 
- can offer other ranges of content - they can scale up or scale down 


## Contact/ Bacground:
* Karl Hughes- https://draft.dev/learn/client-onboarding
- they focus in on recurring in on dev marketing content- ebooks, white paper, guides, blogs
- they have huge pool of software developers that are just writing on the side 
- they have 50-60 active writers
- all practiced software writers 

### Process:
- people usually send list of topics and keywords and any references 
- write then they is tech review, then dev edit and copy edit 
- goal is ready to publish content on a weekly basis 
- delivered in MD files in google doc
- timeline- week and a half to create outlines and briefs- 4 weeks after - 6 week on boarding process


### Pricing 
* $1300 per blog post 1500 to 2500 word range 
* min of 12 a quarter 
* $15600 per quarter- this can help us create a great pool of evergreen content we can use for at least a year.
* contract period 10/26/21 to 02/26/2022

#### Add ons 
* keyword research
* Social media collateral, we include:
  - 2 Tweets
  - 2 Linkedin/Facebook posts
  - 2 Reddit headlines and suggested subreddits
  - 1 Hacker news headline
  - 1 custom image specifically for social media

These are added to the top of the document with each post so your team can simply copy/paste them into their favorite scheduling tool.


### Todos

- [x] request SOW
- [ ] send them topics

_decoded_content.title: 2022 Content Pillars
_decoded_content.description:
## Company narrative strategy:
Category creation.

## Pillars:
* **Beyond ELT: ELT as the wedge**
* **DataOps**
* **Data modernized**

### Beyond ELT
* ELT as the wedge to get started with end to end platform 
* Position Meltano as foundational
* Create more guides on this as starting place 
* Differentiate our approach from just ELT tools - ELt is a good start but not enough 
* content to lower barrier to entry
* lots of how to content 

### DataOps
* how we define data ops and why DevOps best practices can aid data professionals 
* git as an essential part of data profession 
* DataOps as icing on the cake 
* highly focused on pain points 

### Data modernized
* making data professionals superstars
* educate on how we got here and evangelize a better future
* talking high level about future 
* Discussion and forward-thinking focused 
* connecting dots 
* talk about ecosystem

## Content Types:
- blogs
- podcasts
- media
- how to guides 
- video 
- documentation 
- community event content 
- social 
- long-form/whitepaper (gated)
- produced videos
- ads
- email
- newsletter
- talks
- webinars
- medium
- website
- guest / partner content

_decoded_content.title: Support a Python-based Plugin Architecture
_decoded_content.description:
Currently all Python-specific plugin handlers live in our main `Meltano` repo and is installed in a single go.

To make a leaner install, we could (for instance) refactor "Singer EL", "dbt Transform", and "Airflow Orchestrator" into separate repositories.

For each type of plugin we want to support, we'd have to create an interface layer and decide which hooks/notifications/invocations are needed by the respective type of plugin.

Note: The refactoring effort for the Singer EL would likely be very large. It might make more sense to use orchestrators (Dagster or Airflow) first.

## How is this different?

Today, if we want to support Dagster in the same way we support Airflow, we have three levers we can control:

1. CLI-based 'command' definitions. This is basically just aliasing existing CLI commands from the tool. Not capable of deep integrations.
2. Files-based plugins. This is the least robust: we download some pre-configured files into the repo.
3. Python code-based approach. This is the only "deep" integration option we have today. This gives a lot of power to wrap the tool's capabilities, but it also requires expanding the code base of `Meltano` core repo.

This proposal would give an alternate path to the third option, enabling us to write an external plugin definition in python, and import it into the project without having it defined tightly as part of that repo.
